Article Title: 'Aaj jawaab toh banta hai': EC denies charges over polling, counting process before giving Delhi election dates
Article Text:
Sab sawaal ahamiyat rakhte hai, jawaab toh banta hai; aadatan kalam band jawaab dete rahe, aaj rubaroo toh banta hain. Kya pata kal ho ya na hon, aaj jawab banta hai (

'No room for manipulation': What EC said on claims of voter list meddling



'Foolproof': What EC said on EVM tampering allegations



'Why does he want it?' EC over blocking public access of CCTV footage of poll booths



NEW DELHI: Election Commission of India on Tuesday addressed concerns regarding wrongful additions and deletions of voters in the electoral roll and said that the allegations regarding the rigging Electronic Voting Machines were "baseless."Setting a poetic tone, the chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar began with a shayari: "All questions hold importance; answers must follow; out of habit, we kept giving written replies, but today, face-to-face feels necessary; who knows if tomorrow will come or not, today, an answer is due)."The CEC, before announcing the dates of Delhi assembly elections, took the opportunity to offer clarifications on allegations, including EVM tampering , erratic changes in voter list and recent changes in rules by the poll body to prevent public inspection of certain electronic documents.Kumar refuted claims of manipulation in the electoral roll, categorically mentioning that no deletion is made without proper documentation, field verification, and providing the individual an opportunity to be heard.On addition of names to the electoral roll, Kumar said, "Regular meetings are held with the representatives of political parties, who have the right to appoint booth-level agents (BLAs). Weekly lists of claims and objections are shared, and both draft and final rolls are published on the Election Commission's website. Polling station rationalisation is also carried out with the consultation of all the stakeholders."Regarding deletion of names from the list, he said, "Mandatory field verification is conducted by the BLOs, and in cases where deletions exceed 2 per cent of a polling station's voter list, cross-verification is done. Deletions due to death require a certified death certificate, and a seven-day window is provided for objections after notices are published online. Also, the affected voters are given the opportunity for a personal hearing before their names are removed.""Where every vote matters, raising doubts about deletion of thousands of names without evidence is misleading. The processes we follow leave no room for manipulation," he said.He added that political parties were involved at each and every stage of voter list preparation with full disclosure and opportunity to object.CEC said that it was not possible to change the voter turnout and said that it was "misleading to compare final VTR with 5pm data.""...It is impossible to change voter turnout...Some polling parties report at midnight or the next day. Form 17C is matched before counting. There is nothing which VTR does not explain. It explains fully," he said.Addressing the EVM issue, CEC said, "There is no evidence of unreliability or any drawback in the EVM... There is no question of introducing a virus or bug in the EVM. There is no question of invalid votes in the EVM. No rigging is possible. High courts and the Supreme Court are continuously saying this in different judgments... What else can be said? EVMs are foolproof devices for counting. Allegations of tampering are baseless. We are speaking now because we don't speak when elections are on."Kumar also cited court rulings at multiple occasions and said that "courts have ruled on 42 occasions that EVMs are not hackable, allegations of tampering totally baseless.""This is aimed at derailing the electoral process," he added.Further, he said that no discrepancies had been found between votes counted through Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) and Voter Verifiable Paper Audit Trail (VVPAT) slips," he said."Let me tell the nation today. After the Supreme Court mandated in 2019 that five VVPATs must be counted from each assembly constituency, over 67,000 VVPATs have been checked. "This translates to more than 4.5 crore (VVPAT) slips being verified. And let me assure you that not even the difference of one vote has been found with the new machines since 2019," he added.Kumar defended the recent amendment to election rules restricting public access to CCTV footage from polling booths, citing the need to safeguard voter privacy and prevent misuse of data to create false narratives."Why does he want it? Let us ask this question from the person who wants it," Kumar asked as he addressed the reason why the poll body had decided to block public access to CCTV footages of poll booths.The CEC explained that the poll authority has evidence showing how such data could be exploited for machine learning and AI to craft deceptive narratives. He cautioned that even fact-checkers might struggle to distinguish between genuine and AI-generated videos of polling stations.The government, acting on the Election Commission's recommendation, amended the rules last month to limit public inspection of certain electronic documents, including polling station CCTV footage, to prevent potential abuse.This comes amidst the opposition raising concerns regarding irregularities in electoral processes, with AAP national convenor Arvind Kejriwal recently accusing BJP of tampering with voters' lists in Delhi. The former CM had alleged that there was an "unusual increase" in voter list modifications, including both removals and additions, specifically in New Delhi constituency.Congress had also raised similar concerns during Maharashtra and Haryana assembly elections, with Mallikarjun Kharge demanding ballot papers instead of EVMs.Assembly elections in Delhi are set to take place in a single phase on February 5. Votes would be counted on February 8.
Article Summary: The Election Commission of India addressed concerns regarding wrongful additions and deletions of voters in the electoral roll. Chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar refuted claims of manipulation. Kumar: "There is no evidence of unreliability or any drawback in the EVM... There is no question of introducing a virus or bug"

Article Title: Mass deportations under Trump: What it means for immigrants
Article Text:
Sunday’s operation, which led to 956 arrests nationwide, was marked by its scope and visibility.

Poll Is Mass Deportation an Effective Way to Address Immigration Issues? No, It Causes More Harm Than Good Yes, It’s Necessary for Control

For the first time, military aircraft are used to deport undocumented immigrants

Also read:

Why it matters

For undocumented immigrants across the United States, including members of the Indian diaspora, Trump’s aggressive deportation plan ushers in a new era of uncertainty, fear, and potential upheaval.

Sunday’s operation, which led to 956 arrests nationwide, was marked by its scope and visibility. In Chicago, ICE collaborated with the FBI, DEA, US Marshals, and other federal agencies, targeting undocumented individuals, particularly those with prior deportation orders or criminal records.

Trump’s border czar, Tom Homan, defended the high-profile raids, asserting the importance of enforcing laws to deter future immigration violations.

This escalation comes just days after Trump signed a series of executive orders aiming to facilitate mass deportations.

Beyond undocumented immigrants, the ripple effects are felt by visa holders, mixed-status families, and even naturalized citizens, amplifying fear and uncertainty across immigrant communities. For Indian immigrants—the second-largest group overstaying visas in the US—the stakes are particularly high.

The big picture

Multi-agency coordination:

Global repercussions:

Trump deportation plan creates uncertainty for undocumented U.S. farm workers

Between the lines

Zoom in: What it means for Indians

Undocumented Indian Immigrants:

Trump administration steps up deportation efforts

Economic and social fallout

Labor shortages: Undocumented immigrants play critical roles in sectors like agriculture, hospitality, and construction. Mass deportations risk leaving significant labor gaps, driving up costs for businesses and consumers alike.

Psychological toll: Communities report increased anxiety and depression as families live in constant fear. Children in particular suffer as schools and other community spaces lose their sense of safety.

Erosion of trust: Immigrants’ mistrust of law enforcement grows as raids escalate, deterring them from reporting crimes or cooperating with authorities.

The global impact: Trump’s immigration policies are straining diplomatic ties. Colombia’s initial refusal to accept deportees carried by US military aircraft led to threats of trade sanctions and tariffs. Though the impasse was resolved, the episode revealed the fragility of US-Latin American relations under the administration’s hardline stance.

India, too, is monitoring these developments closely. With its large expatriate population in the US, restrictive immigration measures risk souring bilateral relations. Indian government officials have repeatedly raised concerns about the treatment of Indian immigrants, particularly H-1B visa holders.

What they’re saying

Illinois governor JB Pritzker called for balanced enforcement: “We need to secure our borders, but we must also protect law-abiding residents.”

Advocacy groups condemned raids on sensitive locations like churches and schools, with Catholic leaders describing the actions as “turning places of solace into places of fear.”

Tom Homan defended the administration’s approach: “There’s consequences of entering the country illegally. If we don’t show consequences, you’re never going to fix the border problem.”

If you’re in the country illegally, you’re on the table. No one is off the table. Tom Homan, America’s new border czar

What’s next

Trump’s immigration crackdown shows no signs of slowing down. His administration is pushing for:

Increased quotas: Trump has reportedly ordered ICE to raise daily arrest numbers from 300 to 1,200-1,500.

Expanded detention facilities: ICE has called for an additional 100,000 detention beds to accommodate the influx of detainees.

Legislative changes: Executive orders targeting asylum seekers, birthright citizenship, and Temporary Protected Status (TPS) recipients are reshaping the immigration landscape.

Meanwhile, immigrant communities are mobilizing. Legal aid organizations, local governments in sanctuary cities like Chicago, and advocacy groups are stepping up efforts to provide resources, fight deportation cases, and counter the administration’s narrative.

The road ahead remains fraught, but as immigrant communities rally together, they remind the nation of its enduring promise as a land of opportunity and refuge.

Early on Sunday, Chicago became the epicenter of US President Donald Trump ’s escalated deportation agenda. Federal agents, supported by six agencies, launched a series of immigration raids targeting hundreds of undocumented immigrants. The operation, one of the most extensive under Trump ’s administration, aimed to send a clear message about his commitment to immigration enforcement.As per a Bloomberg report, at dawn, agents fanned out across the city. In the Hermosa neighborhood, they knocked on doors, shouting, “Come here,” and “Please open the door.” Many homes stayed dark and silent as immigrants—aware of their rights—refused entry without a warrant. But by mid-morning, fortunes shifted. A 28-year-old Mexican man, previously deported and with a criminal record, was arrested after returning home with tamales, the Bloomberg report said.The raid, live-streamed by Trump border czar Tom Homan and television personality Dr Phil, showcased the scale of enforcement. Immigration and Customs Enforcement(ICE) later revealed that 956 arrests were made nationwide on the same day, underscoring the aggressive push.Trump’s second term has brought intensified immigration crackdowns, reshaping enforcement dynamics. His broader strategy includes:Previously off-limits places like schools and churches are now subject to raids, further disrupting community sanctuaries.Expanded authority for ICE to deport individuals without court hearings is accelerating cases, raising concerns about due process.Sunday’s raid involved ICE, the FBI, US Marshals, and other federal entities, highlighting the militarized approach to immigration enforcement.Resistance from countries like Colombia and Mexico has created diplomatic tensions, though Colombia ultimately agreed to accept deportees after the US threatened tariffs and sanctions.Sunday’s raids reflect not only the administration’s logistical challenges but also the resilience of immigrant communities. Social media alerts, neighborhood networks, and knowledge of legal rights have made it harder for ICE to make arrests.“Usually, it just takes the first arrest and the phone calls start,” said Matthew Putra, acting field director for ICE in St. Paul, Minnesota. This grassroots resistance is complicating the government’s ability to meet Trump’s ambitious deportation quotas.For Chicago’s immigrant population, including its Indian diaspora, the implications are dire:While the majority of Indian immigrants in the US are documented, a significant number overstayed their visas. For these individuals, the specter of raids and deportation has driven them into the shadows, cutting off access to essential services and heightening anxiety.Indian professionals dominate the H-1B visa category, which is under increased scrutiny. While the deportation raids primarily target undocumented individuals, the Trump administration’s broader immigration policies have tightened legal pathways, adding hurdles for Indian workers. Delays, rejections, and visa denials are becoming more common, forcing some to consider returning to India.Families with members of varying immigration statuses face the constant threat of separation. Children who are US citizens may wake up one day to find parents deported. This instability has long-term social and psychological consequences, particularly for young children.Even legal residents and citizens of Indian origin report facing heightened racial profiling and xenophobia. The administration’s rhetoric has contributed to a broader climate of hostility against immigrants, especially those perceived as foreign.(With inputs from agencies)
Article Summary: Sunday’s operation, which led to 956 arrests nationwide, was marked by its scope and visibility. The ripple effects are felt by visa holders, mixed-status families, and even naturalized citizens. Immigrants’ mistrust of law enforcement grows, deterring them from reporting crimes or cooperating with authorities.

New vs Old Tax Regime: Will Old Regime Be Phased Out Soon?

Budget 2025 income tax expectations: Ever since Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman introduced the new income tax regime with reduced tax rates and almost no deductions and exemptions, salaried taxpayers have been wondering whether the old income tax regime will eventually be phased out.The new income tax regime was introduced as an optional tax regime FY 2020-21 onwards. Under the new income tax regime, common and popular exemptions like Section 80C, medical insurance premium, house rent allowance etc. are not included. What it offers is a tax regime with lower tax rates, beneficial income tax slabs and no headache of compliance burden related to deductions and exemptions.Ever since the introduction, the Narendra Modi governments have made various changes in the new tax regime including changing the income tax slab rates to make it more attractive for the taxpayer. For example, the standard deduction from taxable salary was increased to Rs 75,000 from Rs 50,000 (as available in the old tax regime) in Budget 2024.Also Read | Budget 2025 income tax: From higher tax exemption limit to increased standard deduction - top 6 expectations of common man Further, the employer’s contribution to the NPS is allowed as deduction up to 14% of specified salary as compared to 10% of salary in the old tax regime.Most personal tax experts are of the view that the government will phase out the old income tax regime in the coming years. However, they are divided on how soon, with tax experts suggesting that the old tax regime will likely be available as an option for salaried taxpayers for some more years.Apart from the taxes calculated according to the slabs mentioned above, a surcharge will be levied on the income-tax of individuals if their total income exceeds Rs 5,000,000.From FY 2023-24, the new tax regime which was optional earlier, was made the default tax regime unless the taxpayer expressly opted out of the same and selected the old tax regime.“This has resulted in the increase in the number of taxpayers adopting the new tax regime. As per the Central Board of Direct Taxes for FY 2023-25 approximately 72% of the taxpayers adopted the new tax regime as at July 2024 reflecting an increasing trend of taxpayers adopting the new tax regime,” says Parizad Sirwalla, Partner and Head, Global Mobility Services, Tax, KPMG in India.Also Read | Budget 2025 income tax: Top tax reliefs FM Sitharaman should consider in Union Budget Surabhi Marwah, Tax Partner, EY India says, “It seems unlikely that the government will completely phase out the old tax regime in the upcoming Budget. While the new tax regime has gained popularity due to its simplicity, the old regime still offers advantages to taxpayers with claims for higher exemptions and deductions.”“The government may continue to focus on encouraging the adoption of the new tax regime, possibly by making it more attractive, while maintaining both regimes for a transition period,” she told TOI.Kuldip Kumar - Partner - Mainstay Tax Advisors LLP says that the old tax regime is likely to be phased out, and this may happen through the new tax code. “The Finance Minister announced in her budget speech last year, to revamp the existing Income Tax Act,” he explains.“Alternatively, the government may make changes to the new tax regime only to provide relief to taxpayers, leaving the old regime unchanged as it did in last year's budget. This would automatically render the old regime redundant until the simplified tax code is brought into effect,” he told TOI.Aarti Raote, Partner, Deloitte India feels that with a hike in standard deduction and NPS benefits under the new tax regime, more people will adopt it. Given these reasons, the government is likely to phase out the old regime in the coming years, she says.Sundeep Agarwal, Partner, Vialto Partners says, “While the old income tax regime benefits those using deductions, its phase-out under current tax laws seems unlikely. However, with the proposed Direct Tax Code (DTC) aiming to streamline taxation and reduce complexities, dual tax structure may eventually be replaced by a single, uniform regime under the DTC.”“Hence, if the government does consider bringing an end/ sunset to the old tax regime, they may adopt a gradual phased out approach and provide a roadmap of the same in the current Budget scheduled to be presented on 1 Feb 2025,” he tells TOI.
Article Summary: Budget 2025 income tax expectations: The new income tax regime was introduced as an optional tax regime from FY 2020-21. Under the new tax regime, common and popular exemptions like Section 80C, medical insurance premium, house rent allowance etc. are not included.

Article Title: Qualification Of Richest People In The World: Educational qualifications of richest people in the world including Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg, and others
Article Text:
Educational backgrounds of the world’s richest people

Elon Musk

Larry Ellison

Bernard Arnault

Also Read:

Ever wonder if a college degree is the secret to billions? The world's richest people broke not only the bank but also quite some interesting educational paths. Here are the educational journeys of elite Ivy League dropouts and people who followed rather odd routes to great wealth.Did Jeff Bezos dream of e-commerce while studying engineering? What did Elon Musk learn before targeting Mars? Does Bill Gates regret leaving Harvard? Their answers might shock you! Whether they earned fancy diplomas or dropped class to join startups, these 10 billionaires show that the road to riches is as varied as it is inspiring. So get ready to dive into their educational stories.Elon Musk, the CEO of Tesla Motors, attended Queen's University in Canada but would later move to the United States to attend the University of Pennsylvania to pursue degrees in business and physics. His desire was thus fulfilled where he could be more entrepreneurial and up-to-date with the world of technology. His quest for deeper knowledge led him to Stanford University in California to pursue a PhD in energy physics. However, after being at Stanford for only two days, he decided to pursue his entrepreneurial pursuits and left college. Although Musk never completed that program, this educational background largely molded his revolutionary ideas in matters related to technology and business.Jeff Bezos, the founder and executive chairman of Amazon, graduated from Princeton University, where he earned degrees in electrical engineering and computer science. His time at Princeton was pivotal in shaping his future, as the knowledge he gained in these fields laid the groundwork for his innovative work in technology and e-commerce. With a strong foundation in both engineering and computer science, Bezos combined technical expertise with a visionary mindset to revolutionize the retail industry. He founded Amazon, which is today the global powerhouse it is.Larry Ellison initially started as a pre-med student at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign but later left before completion of his studies. He thereafter enrolled in the University of Chicago where he majored in physics and mathematics. But he did not graduate. Even though he dropped out from both high school and the University of Illinois early in his academic life, Ellison had become passionate about technology and innovation, which led to co-founding Oracle as it revolutionized the soft-ware industry. It is an enlightening reminder of how educational pathways are not the definitive route to success; rather, passion sometimes leads to incredible feats.Mark Zuckerberg first went to Harvard University to study psychology and computer science. Yet, after only two years, he quit college and took up the entrepreneurial career to pursue his goals. Focusing on Facebook was much more important to him than any college where he might have spent most of his time developing the social media platform that would change the course of connectivity among online users. Although he did not graduate from Harvard, dropping out marked the beginning of an incredible journey that made him one of the most influential figures in the tech world and one of the wealthiest individuals in the world.Bernard Arnault is the man behind the LVMH empire, which comprises brands such as Louis Vuitton and cosmetics giant Sephora. He graduated from École Polytechnique in Paris with a Bachelor of Arts and Science. This institution formed the basis for Arnault's incredible journey into the world of high-end fashion and cosmetics. His education was well-equipped with the analytical skills and business acumen that would later help him build one of the most influential luxury conglomerates in the world. Arnault's success story shows how a strong academic background can blend with entrepreneurial vision to create global dominance.Larry Page, the co-founder of Google, graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in computer engineering from the University of Michigan. While studying at Michigan, he established a strong background in computer science that eventually made him interested in search engine technology. Page later continued his studies for a PhD in computer science at Stanford University, where he met Sergey Brin. Together, they worked on a research project that eventually became Google. Page left his PhD program to focus on developing Google, but his academic background played a crucial role in shaping the innovative approach that led to the creation of one of the world's most successful tech companies.Sergey Brin graduated with honors from the University of Maryland, College Park, with a Bachelor's degree in mathematics and computer science. He later acquired his Master's degree in computer science from Stanford University. At this time, he was awarded a National Science Foundation Graduate Fellowship, an award that recognizes potential to grow into new talent in technology. This is where Larry Page came into his life, and he and Page started on a journeythat transformed the tech industry itself, making him the man behind Google, the world's leading search engine.Warren Buffett studied business at the University of Nebraska–Lincoln, graduating with a Bachelor of Science in Economics in 1950. After that, he studied economics at Columbia Business School, earning a Master of Science in Economics in 1951. At Columbia, he was under the mentorship of Benjamin Graham, one of the most important economists and investors, whose value investing principles Buffett used to great effect in his investment strategies.Steve Ballmer graduated from Harvard University in 1977, earning a Bachelor of Arts degree in Applied Mathematics and Economics. He later attended Stanford Graduate School of Business, graduating with an MBA in 1980. His academic exposure to applied mathematics, economics, and business paved the way for his professional life at Microsoft. After joining the company in 1980, he became very close to Bill Gates, eventually taking on the position of CEO from 2000-2014 and steering the company through growth that turned it into one of the world's most valuable tech companies.The founder and CEO of NVIDIA, Jensen Huang, has impressive academic credentials. He earned his Bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering from Oregon State University. He further went on to obtain his Master's degree in Electrical Engineering at Stanford University. Huang's education in electrical engineering laid a foundation for his future career in technology and semiconductor industries. In 1993, he founded NVIDIA which he co-founded and made a leader in graphics processing units and AI technology that creates innovations in gaming, data centers, and artificial intelligence.
Article Summary: Elon Musk attended Queen's University in Canada but would later move to the U.S. to attend the University of Pennsylvania to pursue degrees in business and physics. Jeff Bezos, the founder and executive chairman of Amazon, graduated from Princeton University, where he earned degrees in electrical engineering and computer science. Larry Page, the co-founder of Google, graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in computer engineering from University of Michigan.

NEW DELHI: Former Indian cricketer Vinod Kambli has once again found himself in the spotlight, this time due to revelations made by his wife, Andrea Hewitt .In a recent podcast interview with journalist Suryanshi Pandey, Hewitt provided an in-depth look into their personal life, shedding light on the challenges the couple faced, particularly Kambli's struggles with alcohol addiction .Hewitt, a former model, candidly discussed the strained relationship she shared with the left-handed batter and how she overcame the obstacles that arose. According to her, Kambli's battle with alcoholism was a significant hurdle, leading him to undergo rehabilitation at least 14 times.During the podcast, Hewitt revealed that she had contemplated divorce at one point, even going as far as filing for it.“I once thought about it (separating). But I realised that he would be helpless if I leave him. He is like a child, and that hurts me. It makes me feel worried. I would not even leave a friend, and he is obviously more than that,” Hewitt said.Hewitt shared the emotional turmoil she experienced, recounting moments when she would walk away from the situation but then worry about Kambli's well-being, prompting her to return and check on him.“I remember there were moments when I would just walk away. But then I would be worried: Has he eaten or not? Is he on the bed properly? Is he okay? Then I had to check on him, and I would understand that he needed me,” she added.The couple's 17-year marriage reached a turning point in February 2023 when Hewitt approached the police to file a complaint against Kambli, accusing him of domestic abuse .The incident involved Kambli allegedly throwing a cooking pan handle at her while intoxicated, resulting in a head injury for Hewitt.Despite the challenges, Hewitt expressed admiration for her son Jesus Christiano Kambli's understanding of the situation.She praised his ability to comprehend the emotions she was experiencing and the support he provided during the difficult times when they were caught in Kambli's health struggles.“My son Cristiano understood everything, he didn't bother me at all, he understood all the emotions on my face,” she explained.

Budget 2025 income tax expectations : Ever since the last Union Budget was presented in July 2024, the world has seen significant changes ranging from various elections, global economic slowdown, geopolitical developments, volatile Indian stock markets, etc. Having witnessed all of this, the common man awaits with eager anticipation from the Hon'ble Finance Minister as she gears up to unveil her eighth straight budget. Some of the key expectations that individual taxpayers may have are discussed below.It is anticipated that with the thrust of the Government on the adoption of the new tax regime, there may be no changes to the old tax regime. The basic tax exemption limit under the new tax regime is currently at Rs 3 lakh. It is hoped that this limit may be increased to Rs 5 lakh, providing more disposable income for individuals to either spend or save, thereby boosting the overall economy.The full rebate of tax is available up to income limit of Rs 7 lakh currently under the new tax regime. It is expected that this limit can be raised to Rs 10 lakh, offering relief to middle income taxpayers and making it easier for them to manage their finances.Also Read | Budget 2025 income tax: Top tax reliefs FM Sitharaman should consider in Union Budget To protect salaried taxpayers, there is a case in point to increase the standard deduction under the new regime from the current Rs 75,000 to Rs 1,00,000. This increase will help combat inflation and address the higher personal expenses incurred due to changes in work culture, such as working from home, hybrid work, and work from anywhere.n line with the Government's objective of "Housing for All" and fostering home ownership, it is suggested that the Government reconsider allowing deductions for interest on self-occupied housing loans under the new default tax regime.To reduce the carbon footprint and move towards clean energy, the Government should reintroduce the deduction provided under section 80EEB (deduction for interest on loan taken to purchase an electric vehicle) and extend it to the new regime as well.Also Read | Budget 2025 income tax: Individual taxpayers want FM Sitharaman to lower tax rates, make new tax regime more attractive, says survey Currently, if a property seller is a resident, buyers must deduct tax at 1% of the consideration if the property value is Rs 50 lakh or more and file a challan-cum-statement, which is a simple and convenient process. However, if the seller is a non-resident, the buyer must obtain a TAN for this one-off transaction, deduct tax at a higher rate, and file a TDS return, which is a cumbersome process. The government should consider introducing challan-cum-statement for non-resident sellers akin to resident sellers to simplify the process.The proposed measures pave the way for significantly improving financial well-being and stimulate economic growth.
